Variation Example: A judge calls a certain man as a witness & asks him whether he saw something. The man answers, he only heard. The judge dismisses him, saying that anything he heard is worth nothing. As he leaves, the witness produces a powerful fart. The judge reproves him, but the man asks him whether he saw it: anything he heard is worth nothing.

Classifications: Cheater Caught by Seizing on His Own Words
Variation Example: A father warns his sons against red-haired & red-faced men. They stay with a red-haired innkeeper. They like his food so much that they tell him each spoonful is worth ten francs. The innkeeper secretly counts how many spoonfuls they eat. When they go to pay, he demands a great amount of money. Further on, the sons meet a red-faced man & are about to flee. He stops them & asks why, so they tell him about their father’s warning & the innkeeper’s trickery. The red-faced man goes back with them to the inn. The innkeeper is about to slaughter an animal, & the red-faced man contracts to buy a quarter (the shoulder). He draws his sword as if he would slaughter the innkeeper & take a quarter of his body. The innkeeper redeems himself for as much money as the sons had paid for their food. The red-faced man gives them the money.

A trickster (who has been coached by a relative, or who is working with an accomplice) impersonates a man who has died & dictates his will to a notary who does not know about the death. Contrary to a prearranged plan, the new will benefits the trickster (gives him the entire estate).

A butcher sees a dog stealing meat. He runs after it & finds out that it is a lawyer’s dog. He asks the lawyer what the punishment is for this crime & is told how much the damages would be. The butcher tells the lawyer that it was his (i.e. the lawyer’s) dog. The lawyer pays the damages, but calls the butcher back & de mands more money (double) in payment for his advice.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Two men fight over a piece of land that each claims is his own. The case comes to court. The false owner (one or more witnesses) swears a false oath: The perjurer takes earth from his own prop erty & puts it in his shoes (a ladle or comb under his hat). He goes to the property (before the judge) & swears that he is standing on his own ground, or calls on the creator (the ladle, German Schöpfer) or the judge (the comb, German dialect Richter) as witness. The case is decided in favor of the trickster (he is punished through an ordeal or by human or supernatural forces immediately or after death). The tale concludes with an explanation of local property ownership (a warning against false testimony). (2) Through laziness (criminal activities, etc.), a man (Eulen spiegel) falls out of the favor of his king (master). As punishment (to get rid of him), he is banished. The man comes back in a cart with foreign soil (foreign dirt in his shoes) & thus cleverly avoids his punishment. He is reconciled with the king (is banished again; is captured & subjected to a fake execution, & dies of fright).

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Two men leave money with a woman & instruct her to return it only when both of them demand it. Later, one asks for the money & explains that the other has since died. The woman gives it to him. The second man comes & demands the money. The woman will not give it to him so he takes her to court. Her lawyer (Demosthenes) advises her: She should tell the judge about the agreement & offer to pay out the money only when both of the men come & demand it. The case is dismissed. (2) Three men leave money with a banker, with the same instructions as in version (1). One of the three arranges with the others to withdraw some of the money. He tells his companions he will take only a small amount, but he takes the entire sum from the banker. The banker asks the two others, who agree, thinking it is only a small sum. The cheater leaves, & the tale ends as in version (1), following the instructions of a clever adviser.

A merchant going on a journey leaves some iron (iron object, lead, gold) in trust with someone (another merchant, innkeeper, friend, Jew). When he comes back later for his property, the trustee claims that mice (rats) have eaten it. The merchant kid-naps the son of the trustee & claims that a falcon (other raptor) carried him off. The judge decides that the two men should make an exchange. In a Middle Eastern version, the cheated man calls on a trickster (Nasreddin Hodja, Bohlul) for help. This helper threatens to destroy (burn) the house in order to punish the thieving mice. The trustee relents.

A merchant (carpenter, pilgrim) gives his neighbor (friend, cadi, Jew) (a vessel of) gold to keep for him. When the merchant later asks for it back, the trustee gives him (a similar vessel of) copper (brass, tallow) & claims that the gold changed to base metal. The merchant kidnaps the son (children) of the false trustee. He trains an animal (monkey, bear) so that it welcomes the trustee & claims that the boy turned into the animal. The trustee relents.
A borrower returns a pot together with a small one, claiming that the pot gave birth to a child. He borrows the pot again but does not return it, claiming that the pot died.
While counting a hundred eggs, an egg merchant cheats a woman by asking questions about the ages of various people (family members) & adding those numbers to the number he has recorded.

A man refuses to lend his neighbor a clothesline, saying that he needs it to dry flour (grain). When the neighbor questions this, the man replies that he will use his clothesline for anything at all in order not to have to lend it.

Classifications: The Donkey is Not at Home
Variation Example: A farmer wants to borrow his neighbor’s donkey, but the neighbor says it has already been loaned to someone else (sent out to pasture, sent to work, etc.). The farmer hears the donkey braying in its stall (sees it tied up) & says the neighbor must be lying. The neighbor asks why he would believe a donkey rather than a man like himself.

In order to catch hares in his garden, a man (shoe maker) sets a trap with a cord tied to a bell that will ring when an animal is caught. When the game warden learns about this, he goes to talk to the would-be poacher. Just then the bell rings. The two men go together into the garden & find the rabbit in the trap. The poacher takes the animal out, beats it with a stick, & then sets it free, saying, “That will teach you not to come back here!”

A fool murders a man (finds a corpse) whom he throws into a well. His brothers (father) remove the corpse unnoticed & put the carcass of a goat in its place. The fool confesses to the murder & is told he must show the head of the dead man as evidence. He finds only the dead goat & is surprised to see that the murdered man had horns. With this evi-dence, no one believes he committed a murder, & he is set free.

A farmer buys a stallion in order to avoid paying taxes. When the tax collector comes, the stallion copulates with his mare. The tax collector is frightened & runs away. Or, a soldier rides into a village on his donkey. He claims that his donkey can take care of all the villagers’ taxes. When the tax collector comes, the donkey attacks his horse. The tax collector forgives all the taxes owed.

A farmer finds the king’s hawk, which had been lost while hunting, & wants to give it back to the king. He meets a soldier (watchman, Jew, minister, general) who offers to lead him to the king if the farmer will give him half of the reward. The farmer agrees. When they arrive with the hawk, the king asks the farmer what reward he would like. The farmer asks for a beating, half of which is given to the soldier. When the farmer explains their arrangement, the king gives him an extra sum of money.
A youth climbs up the mast of a ship, falls down, & is caught in the rigging. He calls to the sailors, “Can you do that?” They think he fell on purpose & take him for an ex-perienced sailor.
Two swimmers are to compete. One of them takes a knapsack with provisions. His rival gives up the contest.

Classifications: Playing-Cards are my Calendar & Prayer Book.
Variation Example: A soldier (servant) is caught playing cards dur ing church. His sergeant demands that he put the cards away, but the soldier refuses. When the soldier is brought to the major for punishment, he ex-plains that each card has a spiritual significance: the ace is God the Father, the deuce is the dual nature of Christ, the three is the Holy Trinity, the four is the four evangelists, the five is the wounds of Christ, etc., up to ten. Then come the face cards: the four queens are the Virgin Mary & the three women at the Holy Sepulchur, the four kings show the three wise men & the greatest among them whom they came to worship, etc. Then the soldier explains that the deck of cards is also a calendar, with 365 spots, 52 pages & 12 pictures. He lays the jack of clubs aside, saying that this card is not respectable. The major asks what it represents, & the soldier replies that it is the sergeant who accused him of blasphemy. The major rewards the solider with money (and punishes him in addition).

In the 18th century a man is brought before a group of men & asked if he is a monarchist or a republican. He answers, “A republican”, & is beaten because the group of men are monarchists. Some time later, he is questioned again. Now he answers, “Mon-ar chist”. This time the group is republican, so the man is beaten again. The third time this happens, the man answers, “I belong to the devil!” This time no one beats him.

A farmer digs a well, but it caves in. He puts his jacket & cap next to the hole & hides. The passersby think that someone has been trapped in the well & dig to rescue him. When they have repaired the hole, the farmer comes out of hiding & thanks them.

A trickster observes thieves dividing their booty. He ties a red string through a hole in his only coin & puts it in among the thieves’ money. Then he claims that all the money is his, because it includes his marked coin. The thieves give him a share of the booty.

Classifications: Unjust Banker is Deceived into Delivering Deposits
Variation Example: A man (woman) goes on a journey (pilgrimage) and/or gives his money (jewels, other valuables) to an acquaintance (official, religious person, judge) to keep on his behalf. When he asks for his money back, the ac quaint-ance lies & says that he has nothing of that man’s. A friend (wife, ruler) helps the man get his money back by making the cheater believe that if he returns it, he will be given even more. In addition to this European form, this type exhibits considerable variation.

A (blind) man buries a treasure, but is ob served by another man (neighbor). Or the blind man tells his god father where the treasure is hidden. The money is stolen. The blind man tricks the suspect by telling him that he had planned to put the same amount (an even greater sum) of money in the same place . The thief brings the stolen money back in the hope that he can steal double the amount. In the end he gets nothing.

This type exists chiefly in two different versions: (1) A trickster pretends to be a painter & is hired to decorate the walls in the house of a wealthy man. While he works (along with his assistants), his employer pays his expenses (and gives him an ad-vance payment). The trickster paints nothing, but he claims that his paintings can be seen only by persons of noble birth (chaste women). Everyone praises the paintings rather than risk being accused. A fool (foolish woman, soldier) says that he would rather be a bastard, but that he does not see any pictures. (2) A man (two, more) pretends that he can weave fine cloth (cloth-ing, coat, cap), & is employed by a ruler. When the weaver is asked how his work is progressing, he explains that the clothing can be seen only by people of noble birth (chaste women). The ruler comes to be fitted. Neither he nor his courtiers will admit that they can see no clothing. When the ruler goes outside naked, only a child speaks the truth.

Classifications: The Conversation of Two Handicapped Persons
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in three different versions: (1) A one-eyed man tells a hunchbacked man that he took up his burden too soon. “No, it is not too soon” answers the hunchbacked man, “it only looks so to you because you have only one of your windows open”. (2) A young woman jokes with a hunchbacked man, saying that he has too much back. He answers, “Be careful that you don’t end up with too much belly”. (3) A short man tells a one-eyed man that he needs another eye. The one-eyed man answers, “To see a giant such as yourself, I would need two more eyes”.

Classifications: The Horse is Cleverer Than the Priest
Variation Example: A farmer says that his horse is cleverer than the priest, because once the horse has stepped into a hole in the road, he avoids it. In contrast, the priest has had two children by the same woman.

Classifications: Donkey Refuses to Drink after It Has Had Enough
Variation Example: A farmer claims that his donkey is cleverer than he is. The donkey (ox, horse) stops drinking when it has had enough, but he himself always keeps on drinking (to please his friends).

Classifications: An Old Hen Instead of a Young One
Variation Example: A master asks his servant to bring him a young woman, but instead the servant brings an old one. The master dismisses him. The servant tells the mistress why he lost his job, & she gives it back to him.

A man (Gypsy) is caught stealing vege-tables from a garden. He claims that the wind carried him over the fence & also uprooted the vegetables. When he is asked how the vegetables got into his sack, the thief says he was wondering about that himself.
A Gypsy trying to break into a house to steal falls through a hole in the ceiling. He explains that he was only taking the shortest way.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A thief (Gypsy) accidentally comes through the chimney into the living room with the bacon he has stolen. Because he is black with soot, he convinces the inhabitants of the house that he is the devil (he says that the devil sent him with the bacon, & they reply that he should take it back to hell). (2) A thief (soldier, Gypsy) goes into a house to steal bacon (suit). When the owner hears a noise, he comes & finds the thief with the bacon. The thief asks him if he would like to buy some.

A horse thief brought before a judge explains that the horse had been standing across the road. He had intended to jump over the animal but instead he landed on its back, & it ran away carrying him with it.

Traveling companions (pilgrims, friends, brothers, master & servant, clergyman & Gypsy) agree that whichever of them has the most wonderful dream may eat their last loaf of bread. One man stays awake & eats the bread. The next morning, the others tell their dreams: one dreamed that he was in heaven (paradise) & another that he was in hell. The third man says he saw them there in his dream (he had dreamed they were dead), & he ate the bread because he thought they would not need it (would not be coming back).

Classifications: The Learned Son & the Forgotten Language
Variation Example: A farmer’s son, having returned home from college, pretends that he has forgotten his native language or that he can speak only Latin. But when he inadvertently steps on a rake & the handle hits his forehead, he cries, “Damned rake!”

A father sends his lazy son to college. When the son comes home, he demonstrates how successful he was in his studies by putting Latin endings on all his words (uses bits of Latin) until his father loses patience & uses similar formulas to order him to work (until the priest who has been summon to test him throws him out).
A thief tells a farmer to crawl into a tub & sit there without looking out while he says a magic spell (to cure the farmer’s sterility). While the farmer obeys, the thief steals all his belongings.

Classifications: Son Has Only Beaten Father's Cap
Variation Example: A father & son (mother & son, married couple) have an argument during which the son hits his father (pushes him downstairs). Later he claims that he only hit (threw down) his father’s cap (jacket, coat, socks), & it was unfortunate that his father was inside it.

Classifications: The Bear Thought to be a Log
Variation Example: A man sees what he thinks is a tree trunk in the river & swims out to get it. It turns out to be a bear, which catches hold of him. His friends on the bank call out, “Let go of him!” The swimmer answers, “He will not let go of me!”

Classifications: Horse That Will Not Go over Trees
Variation Example: A dealer selling a horse says that it eats too much & will not go over trees. The unsuspecting buyer discovers that the horse bites everyone within reach & refuses to walk over a wooden bridge.
